metadata.case_name: Shrimati Arati Ray Choudhury v. Union of India & Ors.

facts.text: Petitioner is a permanent employee in South Eastern Railway, which runs Higher Secondary Schools for girls at Adra and Kharagpur.
In August 1966, vacancy in Headmistress post at Adra school filled as unreserved by appointing Smt. Gita Biswas, senior most Assistant Mistress.

Headmistress of Kharagpur school due to retire from January 1, 1969; on December 5, 1968, Railway formed panel of four Assistant Mistresses including petitioner (top), respondent No.8 (third, Scheduled Caste).
Interviews scheduled for December 18, 1968 stayed by Calcutta High Court in Writ Petition Civil Rule No. 2117W of 1968 by respondent No.8 for seniority readjustment.
On December 28, 1968, petitioner asked to take charge; promoted January 4, 1969 to officiate as Headmistress on local stop-gap basis without conferring right to post.
Respondent No.8 filed Writ Petition Civil Rule No. 499W of 1969 claiming Kharagpur vacancy reserved for Scheduled Caste; stay on interviews obtained.
Stay in Writ 2117W vacated; fresh notice April 15, 1969 for interviews April 29, stayed by injunction in Writ 499W.
December 24, 1970: Single Judge Calcutta HC allowed Writ 499W, holding post reserved for Scheduled Caste, respondent No.8 alone entitled; petitioner not impleaded.
Appeal No. 454 of 1971 by Union of India dismissed by Division Bench September 14, 1971.
Respondent No.8 filed contempt petitions; in Civil Rule 4014W of 1971, Division Bench June 7, 1972 directed compliance within 3 months, allowing Selection Board to consider suitability.
November 6, 1971: Chief Personnel Officer memo to hold selection for panel of 2: one reserved SC for existing vacancy, one unreserved for unforeseen.
Petitioner filed Writ Civil Rule 1395W of 1972 challenging memo; injunction February 11, 1972 restraining appointment on reserved basis; rivals impleaded August 1972.
Despite injunction, August 19, 1972 letter to respondent No.8 for interview August 30.
Respondent No.9 (Lila Bhattacharyya) obtained injunction in Civil Rule 5680W of 1970 restraining appointment without considering her claim.
Petitioner obtained further injunction September 18, 1972.
October 3, 1972: Single Judge dismissed Writ 1395W without merits, recalling rule due to conflict with prior HC judgment.
Present Writ Petition under Art 32 filed October 11, 1972; Rule Nisi October 23, 1972 with status quo; vacated February 27, 1973.
March 21, 1973: Chief Personnel Officer ordered posting of respondent No.8 as Headmistress subject to conditions.
Adra vacancy in financial year 1966-67 at reserved point but treated unreserved as single vacancy; carried forward till 1968-69.
No vacancy in 1967-68; Kharagpur vacancy in 1968-69 financial year, treated as reserved due to carry forward.

legal_issues.text: Whether the vacancy in the post of Headmistress of Kharagpur school can be treated as reserved for Scheduled Caste candidate under Carry forward rule.
Whether the Carry forward rule is valid or violative of Articles 14 and 16 of the Constitution.

petitioner_arguments.text: Vacancy is unreserved as only one vacancy in recruitment year; Carry forward rule violative of Articles 14 and 16.
Rules on reservation including Carry forward unconstitutional; memo November 6, 1971 to be quashed.

respondent_arguments.text: Vacancy reserved for Scheduled Caste due to carry forward from Adra vacancy; petitioner should have appealed HC dismissal.
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: Carry forward rule post-1963 modifications; model roster

respondent_arguments.text: Petition not maintainable under Art 32 as acquiesced in HC judgment.
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: M. Gopalan v. State of MP; Tilokchand Motichand v. H.B. Munshi

court_reasoning.text: Rejected preliminary objections: HC dismissal not on merits, no res judicata; petitioner not party to prior HC proceedings.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Petition under Art 32 maintainable as HC did not decide merits.

court_reasoning.text: Explained history of Carry forward rule: Post-Devadasan modifications limit total reserved + carried forward to 45% in recruitment year; single vacancy unreserved but carry forward allowed up to 2 years.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Rule no longer excessive, does not exceed 50% or create monopoly.

court_reasoning.text: Adra vacancy 1966-67 (reserved point, single vacancy) treated unreserved, carried forward to 1968-69; Kharagpur vacancy in 1968-69 thus reserved.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Respondent No.8 alone entitled among candidates as sole SC candidate.

court_reasoning.text: Petitioner's construction would render carry forward illusory and perpetuate social injustice.

holdings.text: Carry forward rule, as modified post-Devadasan, constitutional; does not violate Art 14/16.
Kharagpur vacancy reserved for SC due to carry forward from Adra; respondent No.8 entitled to consideration.

precedents_cited.case_name: M. R. Balaji v. State of Mysore
precedents_cited.relevance: Reservation should be less than 50% generally.
Struck down excessive carry forward; each year separate; post-modification rule upheld.
Art 32 not if HC moved unless good reason; no bar if not on merits.

precedents_cited.case_name: M. Gopalan v. State of Madhya Pradesh
precedents_cited.relevance: Discourages direct Art 32 after adverse HC without appeal.
Grievance against HC judgment infringing equality not directly under Art 32.

statutes_cited.name: Constitution of India
statutes_cited.relevance: Enforcement of fundamental rights; equality and equal opportunity challenged by carry forward rule.

outcome.summary: Supreme Court dismissed the writ petition, upholding the validity of the modified Carry forward rule and holding that the Kharagpur Headmistress vacancy was reserved for Scheduled Caste candidate (respondent No.8) due to carry forward from Adra vacancy. Directed end to pending Calcutta HC proceedings.
outcome.relief_granted: None to petitioner; confirmed respondent No.8's entitlement.

key_quotes.text: the Carry forward provision of the rules is violative of articles 14 and 16 of the Constitution
key_quotes.speaker: petitioner

key_quotes.text: in any recruitment year, the number of normal reserved vacancies and the carried forward reserved vacancies together shall not exceed 45 per cent of the total number of vacancies
key_quotes.speaker: court

key_quotes.text: Such a construction is contrary to the plain language of the letter of the Railway Board, the intendment of the rule and its legislative history.
key_quotes.speaker: court
